docs.abstract: Group of American chefs from New England and eastern Canada, including Newfoundland, have been diving deep into their habitat, collecting resources in effort to define Northern food; many restaurants menus feature items indigenous to the area's waters and lands of the region.
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of chefs seeks to give fare from New England and Eastern Canada what Southern dishes have long had: a clear identity and plenty of fans.

headline.print_headline: Chilean Cuisine Rises by Going Back to Its Roots
headline.main: Chilean Cuisine Rises by Going Back to Its Roots

docs.lead_paragraph: Chile is famous around the world for its wine, but until recently its food wasn't known beyond its long borders. Now, several chefs in the South American country's capital are revolutionizing Chilean cuisine one bite at a time.

headline.print_headline: France Forces Labels on Restaurants to Save Homemade Cuisine
headline.main: France Forces Labels on Restaurants to Save Homemade Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: French restaurants microwaving ready-made boeuf bourguignon and veal blanquette will now be exposed by law, in a move the government hopes will preserve the nation's culinary reputation.

headline.main: For ‘Modernist Cuisine,’ Errata Commensurate to the Task

docs.abstract: The six-volume cookbook issues 12 pages of corrections.
docs.lead_paragraph: For those of us who don’t have the $625 (or the upper-body strength) to buy “Modernist Cuisine,” the six-volume, 40-pound high-tech food encyclopedia released with great fanfare last month, the 12 pages of corrections and clarifications that went up on the book’s Web site last week is worth a read for its own sake.
docs.snippet: The six-volume cookbook issues 12 pages of corrections....

headline.main: In New Haven, It's an Adventure in Cuisine

docs.abstract: Patricia Brooks reviews Lalibela, Ethiopian restaurant in New Haven, Conn (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN continues to surprise us with its varied ethnic restaurants. The latest is Lalibela, named in honor of an ancient Ethiopian king and specializing in the food of that African country. This small, attractive newcomer seems well-suited to a college town for three reasons: modest prices, vegetarian dishes and an informal style of dining. We cherished fond memories of dining Ethiopian style in Chicago and New York with sizeable groups of friends, when everyone dug in with gusto, scooping up the food with torn segments of an unusual spongy bread called injera. No forks required or provided.

headline.main: Food at the Ball Park: Now It's Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: FOR generations, hot dogs and beer have been as much a part of the baseball ritual as chewing tobacco and pudgy managers throwing tantrums at home plate. It was inevitable, though, that the food revolution sweeping across the land would scale the walls of the nation's ballparks, threatening to turn our ingenuous national pastime into a food event.

headline.main: DINING OUT French Country Cuisine at Guilford; *Century House

docs.lead_paragraph: GUILFORD CENTURY HOUSE is a less-than-year-old addition to the Guilford restaurant scene-- and a welcome addition at that. It is in an old foundry that has had weathered barn-siding added to the outside. The effect is somewhat bizarre.
